rows.title: 50 years and 3 months
rows.audio_transcript:
Take a minute to think about what you would do if you had 50 or more years to live and note them down on a piece of paper. Take time to reflect on what you have written down. Are these the most important relationships in your life? 

And what would you do if you had only 3 months left?

rows.title: Your child as a 20-year-old
rows.audio_transcript: Close your eyes and imagine the following: Your child or grandchild is grown up. You are about to celebrate his/her 20th birthday. Imagine what he or she will look like at that age. What kind of person do you hope he/she will be? What kind of relationship will you have with your child?

rows.title: My Father/Mother’s Legacy
rows.audio_transcript:
* What positive childhood things do you remember in your relationship with your father/mother/caregiver?
* What negative  childhood things do you remember in your relationship with your father/mother/caregiver?
* What is the one thing about your father/mother/caregiver that you want to take into your relationship with your children?
* What is the one thing about your father/mother/caregiver that you do not want to repeat with your children?

* What does Sarah do to get attention from the mother? Does it work?
* Why is it important for Sarah to get the mother’s attention?
* What behavior is the mother rewarding by responding to the needs of Sarah’s brother?
* Why might it be a problem to say “I will tell your father”?
* What would be a better way to respond?
rows.title: Reflection

rows.audio_transcript:
* Humbly, Sarah was trying to get her brother to play with her.
* Instead of the mother encouraging them to enjoy the play together, she made it worse by shouting at her daughter Sarah. This is common in our everyday lives.
* As parents, we tend to favor the young ones at the expense of the older ones.
* The mother needed to resolve the problem between the two siblings instead of referring the issue to their father.
* She needed to help the children to play together happily

rows.title: Reflection
Strict/Authoritarian
rows.intro_text: Strict parenting has its benefits and also effects.
rows.audio_transcript:
Strict parenting has the following benefits and effects:
* Obedient in the presence of adults
* Do well in school
Its effects include:
* Unhappy and fearful
* Low self esteem
* Problems relating with people
* Cannot cope with frustration

rows.title: Firm/Authoritative Parenting
rows.intro_text: Firm/Authoritative parenting has its benefits and also effects.
rows.audio_transcript:
Firm/Authoritative parenting has the following benefits and effects:
* Behave well
* Do well in school
* Lively and feel secure
* Self-confident
* Able to control their emotions
* Can relate with other people in the home and outside children's right to expression is not respected
* Sometimes children can be misunderstood as being proud
* They can be vulnerable to abuse if they go to an environment where children's right to expression is not respected.

rows.title: Permissive parenting
rows.intro_text: Permissive parenting has its benefits and also effects.
rows.audio_transcript:
Permissive parenting has the following benefits and also effects:
* More resourceful than kids raised by uninvolved or strict parents.
* Cannot control their emotions
* Often rebellious likely to have problems with authorities
* Tend to have problems at school

rows.title: Indifferent/uninvolved caregiver
rows.intro_text: Indifferent/uninvolved caregiver has its benefits and also effects.
rows.audio_transcript:
Indifferent/uninvolved caregiver has the following benefits and also effects.
* Survive on their own but can be dangerous
* Unhappy
* Have problems controlling themselves
* Have low self-esteem
* Lack confidence
* Have problems at school

rows.title: Child's Needs
rows.intro_text: What does your child want from you to grow up well?
rows.audio_transcript:
What does your child want (at different stages of life) from you to grow up well?
Well, children do not develop in isolation but need an environment where their rights are respected.
rows.suggestion_1:
0-5 years 
* Hugs and kisses
* Smiles and playtime
* Regulation of behavior & consistency
* Rules to keep children safe
* Answer their questions
* Love and nurturing
* Eye contact & attention
rows.suggestion_2:
6-9 years 
* Talking and listening time
* Play and have a fun time with you 
* Answers their questions
* Participation & Involvement
* Activities that build on self-esteem
rows.suggestion_3:
10-12 years 
* Support and Guidance
* Establish a routine and teach what is expected of children 
* Approval and encouragement
* Maintain clear rules and limits
* Teach beliefs & responsibility
rows.suggestion_4:
13-17 years 
* Debates and discussions
* Mentoring and direction
* Guidelines, but no rules to
enable decision-making & learning from their mistakes 
* Respect & parents’ support toward independence

rows.title: Reflection
Understanding gender stereotypes
rows.intro_text: Let's reflect upon how gender norms can be harmful to both women and men or girls and boys.
rows.audio_transcript:
* What comes to mind when you hear the words “being a man”? Is it being “father”, “decision maker”, “breadwinner”, “provider”, “strong”, “courageous”, “violent”, “leader”
* What comes to mind when you hear the words “being a woman”? Is it being “mother”, “weak”, “carer”, “beard”, “penis”, “breasts”, “pregnancy”, and “birth”)

rows.title: Understanding gender stereotypes
rows.audio_transcript:
* What things do men do that are considered to be for women?
* What things do women do that are considered to be for men?
* What attributes can a woman take to make her a better wife and mother?
* What attributes can a man take to make her a better husband and father?
* What have you learned from this activity?

* Is such a situation familiar in your community or daily lives?
* What is the most common type of violence practiced against women? Against men? Against children?
* Is there a relationship between power and violence?
* What are the consequences of conflict/violence to women? To the Children? To the Men? To the Family?
* What are some examples of healthy spousal and family relationships?
* How can we make our own relationships less violent?
rows.title: Reflection
Caregiving and fatherhood/motherhood
rows.intro_text: Let’s reflect on the time men and women dedicate to caring for their children and shaping their future.
rows.audio_transcript:
* Think of all typical household duties that take place on a daily basis and are usually performed by women, men and both relating to child care. 
* Write them on a piece of paper separately until they are exhausted.
* Count the number of activities that women, men or both sexes normally do.

Imagine having the following items, two empty boxes, household items such as a radio, phone, plates, baby
oil, clothes, hoe, electronic items, and baby toys.
* Drop in the woman’s box pictures and/or objects of things that women care for, better.
* In the man’s box drop pictures and/or objects of things that men care for, better.
